items.title: House of Huawei by Eva Dou review – bad connection
items.author: Eva Dou
items.summary:
- Huawei is a major player in the high-end smartphone market and telecommunications infrastructure.
- The company faces accusations of espionage and links to the Chinese government amid the US-China trade tensions.
- Eva Dou’s book provides a detailed history of Huawei and its founder, Ren Zhengfei, including the arrest of his daughter, Meng Wanzhou.
- The book presents an even-handed account without speculation, detailing both the successes and controversies surrounding Huawei.
- It raises questions about the nature of Huawei as a company versus a state instrument, and discusses global security concerns related to its technology.
- Dou highlights significant events, such as Huawei’s efforts to provide 5G for the Beijing Olympics and its troubled operations in western countries.

items.title: Ethics watchdog issues conflict of interest warning to Musk’s Doge agency
items.summary:
- A leading ethics watchdog warned Elon Musk regarding his involvement with the Doge agency, claiming its use of encrypted messaging could violate the Federal Records Act (FRA).
- American Oversight expressed concerns over potential conflicts of interest due to Musk's business ties and the agency's significant potential impact on federal operations.
- The watchdog has notified multiple government departments and the National Archives to take action to ensure the preservation of federal records related to Doge activities.

items.title: Thousands of customers affected by outages across Three network in UK
items.summary:
- Thousands of customers in the UK unable to make or receive calls due to outages on the Three network.
- Over 10,000 reports of issues logged on Downdetector.
- Smaller networks Smarty and iD Mobile also affected, relying on Three's infrastructure.
- Three does not have a specific timeframe for resolution but has identified the issue as of 6pm.
- Ofcom states that refunds 'may be appropriate' for affected customers.
- Three's merger with Vodafone approved in a £16.5bn deal last month.
- Data services and emergency calls (999) remain unaffected.

items.title: US meteorologist fired from TV station after criticizing Elon Musk salute
items.summary:
- Milwaukee meteorologist Sam Kuffel was fired from CBS 58 after criticizing Elon Musk’s gesture during Donald Trump’s inauguration.  
- Kuffel had made Instagram posts referring to Musk’s salute as a “Nazi salute,” leading to backlash from far-right radio host Dan O'Donnell.  
- Channel 58 News Director Jessie Garcia confirmed Kuffel's departure in a staff memo, stating that a search for a replacement is underway.  
- Supporters of Kuffel expressed outrage on social media, condemning the station for her firing based on personal social media posts.

items.title: Can Assassin’s Creed Shadows save Ubisoft?
items.summary:
- The video game industry faces a crisis with over 25,000 job losses and 40 studio closures in recent years.
- Ubisoft's recent releases, including Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora and Star Wars Outlaws, have underperformed.
- Assassin’s Creed: Shadows is set in feudal Japan, featuring Yasuke and a shinobi named Naoe as protagonists.
- The game has experienced delays prior to release and has sparked debates over historical accuracy due to its character representation.
- Players can switch between Yasuke and Naoe, offering different play styles from combat-focused to stealth.
- The game promotes a vibrant open-world experience, with more than 1,000 different character behaviors adding depth to the environment.
- Shadows promises enhanced narrative and immersive gaming mechanics, aiming for a polished final product following adjustments.

items.title: Pope warns Davos summit that AI could worsen ‘crisis of truth’
items.summary:
- Pope Francis cautioned at the World Economic Forum in Davos that AI could worsen the 'crisis of truth'.
- He emphasized the need for due diligence from governments and businesses regarding AI's implications.
- The pope highlighted AI's potential to blur the line between human-generated and AI-generated outputs, raising ethical questions.
- AI is seen to potentially improve healthcare, with innovations like Google's AlphaFold expected to accelerate drug discovery.
- The discussion at Davos showed high expectations for AI's role in the workforce, transforming management practices.

items.title: UK competition watchdog investigates Apple and Google’s mobile platforms
items.summary:
- The UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) is investigating the impact of Apple and Google’s mobile platforms on consumers and businesses.
- The CMA will assess mobile operating systems, app stores, and browsers to determine if special regulations are needed.
- This investigation is part of the new regulatory framework under the Digital Markets, Competition and Consumers Act (DMCC).
- The CMA aims to complete the investigation by 22 October, as part of its broader scrutiny of tech companies.
- Sarah Cardell, CMA’s chief executive, emphasized the importance of competitive mobile ecosystems for innovation and growth.

items.title: Microsoft Strengthens Ties with Israeli Military During Gaza Conflict
items.summary:
- Microsoft’s cloud technology and AI systems were increasingly relied upon by the Israeli military during the Gaza offensive that began on October 7, 2023.
- Leaked documents indicate Microsoft made over $10 million in deals to provide technical support, emphasizing its integration into military operations.
- The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) significantly increased their use of Microsoft services, notably Azure, to manage extensive data and intelligence operations amidst the war.
- The collaboration includes sensitive projects, including support for IDF intelligence units like Unit 8200, and significant access to OpenAI’s GPT-4 model.
- There is growing scrutiny and protests in the US regarding the military's reliance on major tech companies amid allegations of violations of international humanitarian law during the conflict.

items.title: Lonely Mountains: Snow Riders review – fun ski-run challenge has a few bumps along the way
items.summary:
- The game is a sequel to *Lonely Mountains: Downhill*, featuring skiing instead of biking.
- Initial gameplay is challenging, with players experiencing difficulties in controlling their skis.
- The game's graphics and sound design are praised for their minimalist style and immersive experience.
- Multiplayer mode currently suffers from performance issues, including lag and connectivity problems.
- Solo mode is highlighted as more enjoyable and relaxing compared to multiplayer chaos.

items.title: UK minister calls TikTok desirable product but admits ‘genuine concerns’
items.author: Peter Kyle
items.summary:
- UK Technology Secretary Peter Kyle expresses genuine concerns about TikTok’s data ownership and use despite calling it a desirable product.
- Recent studies suggest heavy TikTok users in the US showed increased pro-China attitudes, raising concerns about potential psychological manipulation.
- TikTok emphasizes user data protection in the UK, stating it’s operated by a UK-registered company with no Chinese government stake in its parent company, Bytedance.

items.title: Is TikTok a national security threat – or is the ban a smokescreen for superpower rivalry?
items.summary:
- Concerns surrounding TikTok focus on potential national security threats due to user data possibly reaching the Chinese government.
- Donald Trump’s approach includes urging a divestment of TikTok to U.S. ownership, which he suggests is influenced by his significant follower base.
- The U.S. Supreme Court recently upheld opinions expressing national security concerns regarding TikTok.
- TikTok has accessed accounts of journalists, raising issues about privacy, but broader allegations of data misuse remain largely theoretical.
- Debate in the UK is ongoing, with some officials dismissing a nationwide ban despite recognizing security risks.

items.title: Tech titans bicker over $500bn AI investment announced by Trump
items.summary:
- Donald Trump announced a $500bn AI project named Stargate, funded by OpenAI, Oracle, and Softbank.
- Sam Altman, Larry Ellison, and Masayoshi Son were present during the announcement, while Elon Musk was notably absent.
- Musk criticized the project as a financial farce and claimed OpenAI lacked funding.
- The partnership aims to build data centers essential for AI development.
- Satya Nadella of Microsoft mentioned he would invest $80bn in Azure, referencing Musk and Altman's feud as part of the ongoing tensions among tech leaders.

items.title: From crypto bro to commerce secretary pick: Howard Lutnick’s glaring conflict of interest
items.summary:
- Howard Lutnick, CEO of Cantor Fitzgerald, is nominated by Trump for secretary of commerce amid concerns of conflicts of interest related to his ties to the cryptocurrency industry.
- The commerce department affects economic and trade policy, significantly impacting the cryptocurrency world, especially following fraud incidents like FTX.
- Lutnick is a prominent supporter of stablecoins, especially Tether, which is central to the crypto economy, raising ethical concerns over his regulatory influence as head of commerce.
- Tether is the third-largest cryptocurrency by market cap, with about $137bn in circulation; its ties to Cantor Fitzgerald further complicate Lutnick's potential role.
- The Biden administration is reportedly focused on regulating the cryptocurrency world, and Lutnick's ties to the industry could challenge public trust in government leadership.

items.title: The Nintendo Switch 2 reveal was exciting – but will it entice you to upgrade?
items.summary:
- Nintendo announced the Switch 2 following leaks; no details about its appearance yet.
- Scheduled reveal event in April is expected to provide more information.
- The Switch 2 will be more powerful and feature-rich but maintains the same form factor as the original Switch.
- Other hybrid consoles like Steam Deck and PlayStation Portal have emerged since the original Switch.
- Nintendo may not need to rely heavily on hardware sales due to its expanding influence through games and media.
- Financially, Nintendo holds significant cash reserves, allowing for long-term planning and innovation in gaming.
- Actual game content will be crucial for the Switch 2's success, only a new Mario Kart appears confirmed so far.
- A range of nostalgic and innovative titles are hoped for in future announcements, including potential revivals of franchises like Star Fox and F-Zero.

items.title: Competition watchdog role for ex-boss of Amazon UK ‘a slap in face’, say unions
items.summary:
- Doug Gurr, former Amazon UK boss, appointed as chair of the UK’s Competition and Markets Authority (CMA).
- His appointment criticized by unions and consumer activists as a conflict of interest amid new tech investigations.
- Gurr replaces Marcus Bokkerink, who stepped down after a call for regulatory ideas to boost economic growth.
- The CMA is set to launch investigations into tech firms, starting with Google, under a new digital markets regime.
- There are concerns about the CMA's independence and potential favoritism towards big tech companies.

items.title: Elon Musk admits cheating at video games, chat transcript appears to show
items.summary:
- Elon Musk admitted to cheating in video games to achieve high scores, according to a private chat transcript.
- He previously claimed to be in the top 20 players worldwide for *Diablo IV*.
- Musk acknowledged participating in ‘account boosting’, a cheating practice, during a conversation with top player NikoWrex.
- Despite his claims, experts pointed out mistakes in his gameplay during a recent livestream.
- Musk's admission came amid a scandal about his gaming prowess and drew attention after discussions on Joe Rogan's podcast.

items.title: Nick Clegg defends Meta’s removal of Facebook and Instagram factcheckers
items.summary:
- Nick Clegg defends Meta's decision to downgrade moderation and remove factcheckers from Facebook and Instagram.
- Meta announced policy changes promoting more political content, with a new system replacing factcheckers, akin to a community notes approach.
- Clegg claims that Meta continues to spend significantly on safety and content moderation, emphasizing the scale and sophistication of their community standards.

items.title: YouTube star MrBeast joins bid to buy TikTok in US
items.author: null
items.summary:
- MrBeast, a leading YouTube creator, has partnered with Jesse Tinsley to make a bid for TikTok's US operations.
- The bid was announced amid discussions by Donald Trump regarding possible acquisitions by billionaires like Elon Musk and Larry Ellison.
- MrBeast expressed his intent to acquire TikTok in social media posts, aiming to prevent its ban.
- The law firm Paul Hastings stated that MrBeast is the only named member of the investor group.
- Trump valued TikTok at $1 trillion and expressed willingness for Musk or Ellison to make bids.
- TikTok's US operations are uncertain following executive actions by Trump to suspend a law requiring its sale by January 19.

items.title: Trump unveils $500bn joint AI venture between OpenAI, Oracle and SoftBank
items.summary:
- Donald Trump announced a $500bn joint venture, named Stargate, involving OpenAI, Oracle, and SoftBank.  
- The project aims to create data centers across the US and generate over 100,000 jobs.  
- The initiative seeks to maintain the US's competitive edge against China in AI.  
- Trump indicated plans to expedite energy infrastructure development via emergency declarations.  
- The announcement follows Trump's reversal of Biden's AI safety standards executive order.  
- Initial projects will start in Texas, with broader evaluations for additional sites nationwide.

items.title: Germans respond to Musk’s apparent Nazi salute
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s gesture, resembling a Nazi salute, sparked angry reactions across Europe, particularly in Germany.
- Michel Friedman condemned Musk’s actions as a disgrace and a dangerous precedent for free expression.
- Charlotte Knobloch of the Jewish community emphasized Musk's political interference as more concerning than the gesture itself.
- German Chancellor Olaf Scholz criticized Musk's support for extreme right positions, calling it unacceptable.
- Legal experts suggest that proving malicious intent behind the salute is necessary for prosecution under German law.
- The US Anti-Defamation League stated that Musk's gesture was awkward and not intended as a Nazi salute.
- Debate continues in Germany over whether the gesture was accidental or deliberate, with some journalists asserting it was unequivocally a Hitler salute.

items.title: Digital passports among IDs to be available in UK government app
items.summary:
- UK citizens will soon be able to carry digital passports in a government app alongside other ID cards.
- Announced by Secretary Peter Kyle, the app aims to simplify interactions with government services, launching in June.
- Initial credentials will include a driving licence and a veteran card, with future access to student loans, benefits, and more.
- Digital passports will exist alongside physical copies; use at border crossings depends on other countries’ systems.
- The app will enable sharing of ID easily, aiming for a more efficient approach to public services, especially for younger users.
- Security measures like facial recognition will be part of the app to protect user data.

items.title: I set out to study which jobs should be done by AI – and found a very human answer
items.author: Allison Pugh
items.summary:
- A nurse practitioner values the human element in nursing, emphasizing the importance of acknowledging suffering.
- Human interaction is crucial in various professions (e.g., nursing, teaching, therapy) for positive outcomes.
- 'Connective labour' is defined as the work of seeing and being seen, critical for dignity and understanding among individuals and communities.
- Being seen creates dignity and fosters trusting relationships, enhancing personal and community well-being.
- There is concern about the rise of AI in replacing human interactions and its impact on essential 'connective' roles in society.

items.title: Robot packers and AI cameras: UK retail embraces automation to cut staff costs
items.summary:
- UK retailers are investing in automation technologies like electronic shelf labels and robot packers to address rising labor costs.
- The national minimum wage increase from April will lead to higher staffing bills, prompting retailers to consider automation.
- A third of retail finance directors plan to use more automation in response to increased employer costs, ranking behind raising prices and reducing head office jobs.
- Electronic shelf labels are set to be introduced across UK high streets in 2025, improving pricing efficiency.
- Self-service tills are expanding beyond supermarkets into fashion and homeware sectors, with several retailers piloting new technologies.
- Warehouse automation is increasing, with a reported 31% rise in assembly line robot sales, while AI solutions are enhancing inventory management and customer interactions.
- Retailers like Sainsbury’s and Tesco are using AI for stock forecasting and route optimization, indicating a growing trend towards integrating AI into retail operations.

items.title: ‘It’s a nightmare’: couriers mystified by the algorithms that control their jobs
items.summary:
- Couriers in Ballymena, Northern Ireland, express confusion over algorithms controlling gig work and pay.
- A campaign has been launched for transparency from Uber Eats, Just Eat, and Deliveroo regarding how these algorithms work.
- Couriers face issues such as being logged out or deactivated without clear reasons, contributing to mistrust of the systems.
- A specific case highlighted includes a courier losing half of their income suddenly due to lack of clarity on app functionality.
- The article discusses the diminishing wages faced by couriers and the stress caused by unpredictable job offers.

items.title: Signature moves: are we losing the ability to write by hand?
items.summary:
- The autopen, a device that replicates signatures, is used in American bureaucracy but raises questions about authenticity and individual expression.
- Handwriting, particularly cursive, is declining; students struggle with writing cursive due to lack of education on the subject and some cannot read it at all.
- Fewer people engage in handwriting for personal use, leading to a loss of cognitive skills and the sensory pleasure associated with writing by hand.
- Research indicates that handwriting is beneficial for learning, with studies showing that handwritten note-takers perform better academically than those who use laptops.
- The decline of handwriting may have long-term negative implications for communication and cognitive development, making it akin to a species decline in ecology.

items.title: Trump signs executive order to pause US TikTok ban
items.author: Donald Trump
items.summary:
- Trump has signed an executive order suspending the sale of TikTok for 75 days.
- The order allows time to determine a course that protects national security and avoids abrupt shutdowns.
- It directs the attorney general not to enforce a previous law mandating TikTok's sale or closure.
- Advocates of the ban cite security concerns due to TikTok's ownership by ByteDance, linked to the Chinese government.
- Trump's previous stance on TikTok has shifted due to popularity and political contributions from TikTok investors.
- The US Supreme Court heard arguments regarding the TikTok ban earlier this month.

items.title: Elon Musk appears to give fascist-style salute after Trump inauguration – video
items.summary:
- Elon Musk appeared to give a fascist-style salute during Donald Trump's presidential inauguration celebration.
- The event took place at Capital One Arena in Washington DC.
- Musk thanked Trump supporters for 'making it happen'.
- [US Politics live – latest updates](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2025/jan/20/president-trump-inauguration-swearing-in-timing-schedule-live-updates?page=with%3Ablock-678e0af78f080f46037df01c&filterKeyEvents=false#liveblog-navigation)

items.title: Elon Musk appears to make back-to-back fascist salutes at inauguration rally
items.summary:
- Elon Musk made controversial fascist-style salutes at Trump’s inauguration rally.
- He expressed gratitude to supporters, predicting a future with secure cities and borders.
- The gestures drew backlash, with comparisons to Nazi salutes, described by the Anti-Defamation League.
- Social media reactions included shock and condemnation.
- Musk has faced ongoing criticism for his association with far-right movements and leaders, including a recent meeting with Alice Weidel.

items.title: The Brutalist and Emilia Perez’s voice-cloning controversies make AI the new awards season battleground
items.summary:
- AI technology is becoming a controversial factor in the movie awards season, with major films using voice-cloning techniques.
- 'The Brutalist' employed AI for Hungarian dialogue, with editor Dávid Jancsó utilizing software from Respeecher to blend actors' voices.
- Voice-cloning was also used in 'Emilia Pérez' to enhance the singing of actress Karla Sofía Gascón.
- In contrast, the horror film 'Heretic' has explicitly stated that no generative AI was used in its production.
- The use of AI in film has raised concerns among actors and writers, leading to strikes for regulations against AI in creative processes.
- Filmmaker Paul Schrader shared his experiences using AI for script ideas, highlighting a shift in creative approaches.
- The impact of AI on the upcoming Oscars is uncertain, with nominations to be announced on January 23.

items.title: Why is TikTok working again in the US as Trump takes office?
items.summary:
- TikTok restored its service in the US after Trump assured it wouldn't face penalties for continuing operation.
- The app had initially shut down due to fears of a federal law requiring it to divest from Chinese ownership by January 19.
- Trump's executive order may allow TikTok to operate temporarily without facing a ban, but long-term resolution is uncertain and requires compliance with US law.

items.title: Elon Musk stands accused of pretending to be good at video games. The irony is delicious
items.summary:
- Elon Musk claimed to be among the best **Diablo IV** players, supported by leaderboard stats.
- During a live stream of **Path of Exile 2**, viewers noticed his character had unusually high gear and his gameplay revealed inconsistencies.
- Accusations arose suggesting Musk may have used account boosting services to enhance his gaming image.
- This incident sparked backlash from the gaming community, including notable streamer **Asmongold**, who called out Musk.
- Musk's partner, **Grimes**, publicly defended him, claiming he had exceptional gaming achievements.
- The article explores the irony of Musk being accused of faking gaming skills, a common stereotype directed towards women in gaming.

items.title: AI tool can give ministers ‘vibe check’ on whether MPs will like policies
items.summary:
- A new AI tool named Parlex can warn ministers about potential unpopularity of policies among their MPs.
- It uses historical parliamentary contributions to predict reactions to policies like the 20mph speed limit.
- The tool aims to help civil servants understand political climates and prepare strategies before proposals are formally made.
- AI initiatives are part of a broader government plan to enhance the UK's AI capabilities, with significant investment.
- Other AI tools in development include Redbox and Consult to improve efficiency in government processes and save costs.

items.title: Inside I was doing the Mario jump – how one artist became a key player in Nintendo’s story
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- In 1889, Fusajiro Yamauchi founded Nintendo in Kyoto, originally as a hanafuda playing card company.
- Takaya Imamura, an art student inspired by video games, joined Nintendo in 1989, the company’s 100th anniversary.
- Imamura started working on iconic games like F-Zero, Zelda: A Link to the Past, and Star Fox, designing beloved characters.
- He contributed to Nintendo 64's Majora's Mask, creating memorable elements like the moon and character Tingle.
- Imamura left Nintendo in 2021 to become an indie developer and is releasing a game called Omega Six on February 28, 2025.

items.title: Donald Trump meme coin price tanks after wife Melania also launches token
items.summary:
- Melania Trump launched a cryptocurrency meme coin, $Melania, impacting the price of her husband’s coin, $Trump.
- $Trump's price dropped over 50% from $75 to $30 after $Melania's launch, affecting market capitalization.
- The price of $Trump previously surged to over $70, reaching a valuation of more than $14bn.
- $Melania's market cap peaked around $13bn shortly after launch.
- Analysts noted the dramatic price drops, with significant sell orders occurring during $Melania's launch.
- Bitcoin reached a record high of $108,943 amid the fluctuations in meme coin prices.

items.title: TikTok says it is restoring service in US after Trump vowed to delay ban
items.summary:
- TikTok announced it is restoring its services in the US following Trump's pledge to delay the ban for the app.
- Trump plans to sign an executive order granting TikTok more time to find a buyer, proposing a 50% ownership stake by a US entity.
- TikTok had temporarily ceased operations affecting 170 million users in the US after a law mandated its sale due to national security concerns.
- Trump thanked for providing clarity for TikTok’s service to continue, emphasizing First Amendment rights.
- Some users reported the app was functional again shortly after Trump's announcement.
- Concerns persist regarding Chinese data access and manipulation through TikTok's algorithm.

items.title: Nicola Jennings on Donald Trump’s inauguration – cartoon
Who banned TikTok? Politicians toss culpability like a football
items.summary:
- The US government banned TikTok on January 19, citing concerns over Chinese influence and data collection.
- The Protecting Americans From Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act was signed in April by President Biden, enabling the ban.
- Neither Congress nor the courts have provided evidence that the Chinese government manipulated TikTok content.
- The ban's enforcement is contested, with suggestions to sell TikTok to American owners as a solution, although China opposes this.
- Trump initiated the original ban in 2020 but now expresses intentions to permit the app under American ownership and may reverse the ban shortly after taking office.

items.title: Would you let AI choose your outfits?
items.summary:
- The author, overwhelmed by choices and personal style after having a second child, turns to an AI styling app to assist with outfit selection.
- Various apps like Whering, Indyx, and Acloset help users create outfits from their existing wardrobes or suggest new looks using AI.
- Critics, including a personal stylist and an AI expert, express concerns that AI may reduce individuality and push towards generic fashion choices.
- The author experiments with an AI-generated outfit for a week and discovers a renewed sense of style, although some AI suggestions don’t suit her specific needs.
- Despite initial skepticism, the experience reignited her personal style, prompting a reconsideration of what fashion means to her.

items.title: Should I be worried about my obsessive TikTok use? My ‘For You’ page doesn’t think so
items.author: Emma Beddington
items.summary:
- The US TikTok ban is causing users to share farewell messages, satirizing security concerns.
- Users express gratitude for TikTok's targeted content, claiming it has positively impacted their lives.
- Anecdotes include users receiving personal insights and support from the algorithm, reflecting on how it influenced their decisions and perspectives.
- The author humorously reflects on the content of her For You page and ponders the implications of TikTok's data practices.

items.title: MrBeast’s degrading game show is a dystopian nightmare – perfect for America in 2025
items.summary:
- MrBeast's Amazon TV series, *Beast Games*, has become the No 1 unscripted show on Amazon with over 50 million viewers in 25 days.
- The show's production costs exceeded $100 million, making it the most expensive competition show in history.
- *Beast Games* imitates the aesthetics of *Squid Game*, featuring elements such as a pastel color scheme and a cash prize of $5 million.
- Critics argue that the show reflects American excess and greed, typifying a 'dystopian' reality competition.
- The show presents a troubling narrative that frames wealthy individuals like MrBeast as benevolent figures while subjecting contestants to humiliation for entertainment.
- Contestants have filed a lawsuit alleging mistreatment and poor conditions during filming, contributing to the show's controversial reputation.

items.title: ‘Young women can fall pregnant very easily’: inside the wild west of smartphone fertility apps
items.summary:
- Apps that predict fertility windows may mislead users, risking unplanned pregnancies.
- Millions of UK women use such apps, with many claiming to help avoid pregnancy.
- The accuracy of these apps is questionable, often relying on unreliable data.
- Studies indicate a rise in women using natural contraception, coinciding with increased pregnancies among users of these apps.
- Experts call for regulation to ensure safety and accuracy of fertility apps, as only one has been approved for contraceptive use in the UK.

items.title: Cringing before the tech giants is no way to make Britain an AI superpower
items.summary:
- Sir Keir Starmer delivered a speech on AI at University College London, calling it the defining opportunity of our generation.
- He announced a 50-point AI Opportunities Action Plan designed by Matt Clifford, emphasizing Britain's potential as an AI superpower.
- Concerns raised about Clifford's influence due to his prior wealth from tech investments and the risks of tech firms violating copyright.
- The Creative Rights in AI Coalition criticized claims of uncertainty in the UK text- and data-mining regime, asserting copyright laws are clear.
- The plan includes building national computing infrastructure, increasing university research capacity, and training AI professionals, which may be costly.
- There is a need for the UK government to engage more effectively with giant tech corporations and not adopt a servile approach.
- Economic experts suggest the general economic impact of AI may be smaller than anticipated in the short term, indicating that becoming an AI superpower will take time.

items.title: The Westminster whistleblower: how my friend Sergei tried to expose the Kremlin plot against Britain
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- In spring 2022, Sergei Cristo, a Russian-born British citizen, sought to expose a Kremlin plot against Britain.
- Cristo attempted to report Russian influence operations in the UK, particularly concerning Sergei Nalobin, a suspected spy.
- He initially approached MI5 but was met with indifference, prompting him to escalate his concerns to the police and the intelligence and security committee.
- Cristo's previous whistleblowing efforts against the Conservative Friends of Russia were successful but left him frustrated over continued lack of investigation.
- The Russia report published in 2020 revealed the UK government's failure to address Kremlin interference in politics, highlighting the urgency for further inquiry into foreign influence.

items.title: TikTok goes dark in the US ahead of ban
items.summary:
- TikTok ceased operations in the US as a federal ban is set to take effect.
- The app is unavailable on iOS and Android app stores, following a law mandating its sale or shutdown.
- TikTok argued divestment is impractical and has fought the ban in court, which was upheld by the US Supreme Court.
- Users received messages indicating they can no longer access TikTok, anticipating maintenance issues.
- The ban followed a long struggle, beginning with former President Trump's initial attempts in 2020 to ban the app.
- TikTok's user base in the US is approximately 170 million individuals.
- President Biden stated that TikTok should remain available under American ownership, while Trump intends to seek a resolution post-inauguration.
- TikTok users are reportedly shifting to alternative apps like Xiaohongshu, amidst anticipation of Trump's intervention.

items.title: Trump likely to grant TikTok a 90-day reprieve from US ban
items.summary:
- Donald Trump announced he will likely give TikTok a 90-day reprieve from a US ban after taking office on Monday.
- The decision is pending a Sunday deadline for TikTok's parent company to sell to a non-Chinese buyer to avoid a ban under US law.
- TikTok's CEO expressed gratitude and emphasized the need for a solution to ensure the app's availability in the US.

items.title: Panic Grips US Music Industry as TikTok Faces Ban
items.summary:
- TikTok is crucial for music promotion, with about 40% of marketing agencies relying on it for campaigns.
- The US Supreme Court is deciding on a potential ban for TikTok over national security concerns.
- TikTok has transformed how artists rise to fame, with several recent hits propelled by the platform.
- A US ban could drastically disrupt the music industry as TikTok serves as a major influencer for trends on Spotify globally.
- Marketers advise artists to diversify their platforms and not rely solely on TikTok.
- Alternatives like Xiaohongshu pose challenges for music promotion due to limited sound libraries.
- Some in the industry hope for a creative renaissance away from the algorithmic pressures of TikTok.

items.title: Never have stale crisps again… nine invaluable things I’ve learned from TikTok
items.summary:
- Average TikTok user spends nearly [one hour each day](https://www.oberlo.com/statistics/average-time-spent-on-tiktok).
- US Supreme Court rejected an appeal against a TikTok ban due to national security concerns on Jan 17, 2025.
- TikTok's parent company ByteDance argues the ban violates free speech for 170 million users.
- Users have started migrating to the Chinese app [Red Note](https://www.theguardian.com/media/2025/jan/16/rednote-tiktok-social-media-china).
- Videos titled "Things I learned on TikTok" have showcased positive lessons amidst criticism of the platform.
- Nine lessons include using a yoga mat under cushions and methods to keep crisps fresh without a clip.
- A popular lesson is to roll lemons before squeezing for maximum juice.

items.title: Chinese rival app Xiaohongshu is overwhelmed by ‘TikTok refugees’ in US
items.summary:
- Over 3 million US users signed up for Xiaohongshu, also known as RedNote, as TikTok faces a potential ban.
- The US Supreme Court upheld the ruling against TikTok, increasing the influx of users seeking alternatives.
- Xiaohongshu is a Chinese app operating under strict content censorship, posing challenges for newly arrived users regarding sensitive topics.
- Moderators are scrambling to manage content in line with Beijing's guidelines, despite the rapid international user growth.
- Concerns rise about censorship effectiveness and the feasibility of cross-cultural communication on the platform.

items.title: When kids set their parents’ screen time rules: ‘I hit my limit before I even get out of bed’
items.author: Zoe Williams
items.summary:
- Discusses the impact of screen time on children’s development and mental health.
- Highlights the lack of focus on adult screen time and its effects on family dynamics.
- Chronicles Zoe's experiment of having her son set her screen time limits over a period of ten days, ultimately reducing her daily average to 2 hours 52 minutes.

items.title: The tech bros have front-row seats at Trump’s inauguration, but what they want goes way beyond that
items.author: Quinn Slobodian
items.summary:
- Joe Biden's farewell speech characterized the U.S. as an oligarchy, warning about the power of the ultra-wealthy.
- At least 13 billionaires are set to hold government positions in the upcoming Trump administration, with a cabinet worth at least $7 billion.
- The rise of tech billionaires is notable, with figures like Elon Musk and David Sacks taking prominent roles.
- Tech leaders seek to influence regulations and maintain favorable tax conditions, reflecting a merger of corporate and political power.
- There are emerging radical ideas among Silicon Valley elites about restructuring nation-states, indicating a possible shift in loyalty away from traditional governance.
- Biden's acknowledgment of the threat posed by affluent oligarchs highlights the need for political action against their influence.
